subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Using Quick Script to teach English sounds
msgSnippet: I did this with my Japanese students.  It does not work well.  First of all, the dictionaries they use for pronunciation will be international phonetics so
messageBody:
I did this with my Japanese students.  It does not work well.  First of all, the dictionaries they use for pronunciation will be international phonetics so some students will see that it is not practical to study quick script instead of the phonetic symbols.  And, you will have to endure complaints.  Moreover, quick script takes time to learn just as much as international phonetics study would. 

I enjoyed teaching the students Shaw's alphabet at the time but I could feel the resistance and if that is your personal motive for teaching them, it certainly will be advantageous for you but not for the students who will probably not use it anyway.  If you persist in doing this, let me know if you succeed at it.

A sharing of a personal experience of mine.

Good Luck

Sid

--- On Sat, 4/24/10, kenhaile <kenhaile@...> wrote:

From: kenhaile <kenhaile@...>
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Using Quick Script to teach English sounds
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Date: Saturday, April 24, 2010, 7:49 AM

 

Greetings -

I have just joined the group. I am a native English speaker living in South America teaching English to Spanish speakers. I'm interested in learning Quickscript to teach English sounds to my students. When I teach English sounds using the International Phonetic Alphabet, my students confuse pronunciation of the IPA letters with their own native language letters. I've been looking for something to represent a sound without using familiar letters from the alphabet. Quickscript seems to me to be a great alternative.

I've used two sources to determine the Quickscript equivalent to the IPA symbols:

http://www.omniglot .com/writing/ quikscript. htm
http://home. wanadoo.nl/ uln/quickscript/ quikscriptmanual .pdf

I have created a table associating both the IPA and Quickscript symbols. You download it here:

http://sites. google.com/ site/kenseflstud ents/resources/ IPAQuickScript. jpg?attredirects =0&d=1

Or view it here:

http://sites. google.com/ site/kenseflstud ents/resources/ IPAQuickScript. jpg?attredirects =0

I would appreciate the help of anyone that would tell me if my associations are correct. I've included the number of each Quickscript symbol in my table so that corrections may be indicated by numbers.

Thanks in advance for any help you might give!

Ken
